pt: {sc}malign{/sc} {sc}traduce{/sc} {sc}asperse{/sc} {sc}vilify{/sc} {sc}calumniate{/sc} {sc}defame{/sc} {sc}slander{/sc} mean to injure by speaking ill of. {sc}malign{/sc} suggests specific and often subtle misrepresentation but may not always imply deliberate lying.

pt.t: the most {it}maligned{/it} monarch in British history

pt: {sc}traduce{/sc} stresses the resulting ignominy and distress to the victim.

pt.t: so {it}traduced{/it} the governor that he was driven from office

pt: {sc}asperse{/sc} implies continued attack on a reputation often by indirect or insinuated detraction.
{sc}vilify{/sc} implies attempting to destroy a reputation by open and direct abuse.

pt.t: no criminal was more {it}vilified{/it} in the press

pt: {sc}calumniate{/sc} imputes malice to the speaker and falsity to the assertions.
{sc}defame{/sc} stresses the actual loss of or injury to one's good name.
{sc}slander{/sc} stresses the suffering of the victim.

dt: {bc}the utterance of false charges or misrepresentations which defame and damage another's reputation
{bc}a false and defamatory oral statement about a person {dx}compare {dxt|libel||}{/dx}

et: Middle English {it}sclaundre, slaundre{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}esclandre{/it}, alteration of {it}escandle{/it}, from Late Latin {it}scandalum{/it} stumbling block, offense {ma}{mat|scandal:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: the utterance of false charges or misrepresentations which defame and damage another's reputation
a false and defamatory oral statement about a person
